moves.1. e4: This game was a training match with a teammate of mine.  We both have room for improvement, so welcome any and all comments to help us all improve together.
moves.1... e6: French Defense.  Fairly common response to e4.  Another benefit of the French is that it precludes my favorite, King's Gambit.
moves.3. Nd2: Protects e4 pawn, provides development of knight, and also allows an eventual c3 push to protect d4.
moves.3... c5: Great counterattack to the center and provide an obvious recapture point via Bxc5.
moves.4. Ngf3: Develops and links the remaining knight and provides protection for d4
moves.5. exd5: Regaining pawn parity and offering some counterplay options and multiple paths for continuation.
moves.5... Qxd5: I think that this play is better than exd5
moves.6. Bc4: Developing the bishop and threatening the queen.
moves.6... Qd6: The choices for where to put the queen are more numerous now.  I think Qd6 is the best play.  Another option worth considering is Qc5.
moves.8. Nb3: Allowing space for DSB to develop and threatening recapture of d pawn.
moves.8... Nc6: Natural development and adding some protection to the d4 pawn.
moves.9. Nfxd4: There is always a consideration of which piece to use for capture when you have multiple options.  Of the two knights I like this one better, because I think it is more likely to cause Black to recapture with the knight.
moves.11. c3: Allowing some more mobility options for the queen.
moves.12... Qc5: I might have considered Rd8 or Qc7 here.  Black threatens the bishop prompting action.
moves.13. Bxf6 Bxf6 14. Bd3: Adding some options for eventual Qc2 and/or Bh7+.  Note that threat of Bh7+ prevents loss of the c pawn.
moves.14... b6: I liked Rd8 here better, but the intent is to give the LSB a development spot.
moves.15. Nb3: Denying the LSB a chance to develop yet.
moves.15... Qc6: Giving potential for Bb7 to threaten mate.
moves.16... Rd8: A small mistake here.  While it does prevent the immediate B4 it does cough up a pawn for free.
moves.17. Qc2 g6: This move is a blunder.  To save the pawn Black missed the skewer threat.
moves.18. Be4 Rd5: Best option to prevent outright lose the rook at a8.
moves.19. Bxd5: A mistake on my part.  Just moved too quickly.  c4 wins the rook.
moves.20... Qc6: Keeping the potential mate threat alive on the main diagonal.
moves.21. Qe4: My intent here was to force a queen trade.  I might have opened more options by Nd4 instead.  Although I am up a bishop for a rook (instead of a full rook!) the two bishop advantage can eventually prove problematic in an open board.
moves.23. Re2: Hoping for a rook battery soon.
moves.23... Rc8: Perhaps Bd5 to take away the rook file and centralize the bishop.
moves.24. Nd2: I probably should have played Rd7 instead to allow me to double up rooks on the open file
moves.25. Rb1: Ree1 may have been a better play.
moves.28... Bb7 29. Rbd1 Bd5 30. b3: Protecting the a pawn and setting up a c-pawn push.
moves.30... Bf6 31. c4 Bb7: I thought Black would trade here instead.
moves.32. Nb5:
Missed opportunity on my part.
32.	Nxe6+	fxe6
33.	Rxd8	Bxd8
34.	Rd1	Bxg2
35.	Rxd8

would have netted two free pawns and ripped apart Black's pawn structure.
moves.32... Re8 33. Rd7: Looking for a free pawn instead.
moves.34. Rxa7 Rd8: Taking the free file and potentially making it difficult for my rook to escape.
moves.35. Kf1: To allow my e1 rook to move.
moves.35... Rd2: Perhaps with an eye towards Bd4 and a chance at perpetual check to force a draw.
moves.36. Nc7: I looked long and hard at Rxe6 but ultimately opted for this play just in case black decided to play Bd4.  Black has a couple of options here on defense.
moves.36... Bd4: Blunder for Black.  Best play was Bd7.
moves.37. Nxe6+: This play will break Black's dual bishop threat and allow some rook action in Black's backyard.
moves.37... Kf6 38. Nxd4 Rxd4 39. Ree7: Now Black has some ugly choices left.
moves.39... b5: Threatening Bxb5+ if the c-pawn captures.
moves.40. Rac7: Prolonging the moment of Rxf7+ and offering some counter-capture options on the Black bishop.
moves.40... Be4: Not the best play as it locks in Black's remaining rook.
moves.41. Rexf7+ Kg5: Note that if Black moved his king towards the center bad things could have happened.
moves.42. Rfd7: I also considered cxb5 instead but felt it more important to get rid of his last remaining rook threat.
moves.42... Rxd7: I think Bd3+ was a better play.
moves.43. Rxd7 bxc4 44. b4: I can trade my rook for his pawn and bishop (if not just take the pawn outright) and the protected passed pawns will guarantee a win.  If I retake the pawns are isolated and not as powerful.
moves.44... c3 45. Rc7: Overall a good game on both sides.  Black made a few mistakes that put him behind early and those compounded over time, but still a strong showing.  Appreciate your comments and rating.
